parameters.source_text:
The case of Danny
Ten-year-old Danny has neurofibromatosis, which required removal of a major fibroma in his left tibia when he was only two. (His mother had previously died of the disease.) Bone was taken from his right fibula in an attempt to strengthen the left tibia, but after 15 months in plaster, his lower left leg had to be amputated. His right leg was weakened by the surgery, and he then underwent two attempts at osteostomy to treat a valgus right foot (one that rolls over). Now he is undergoing limb lengthening of the right fibula. As he describes it, ‘I’m going to have a bone graft in my right leg. Take a little bit from here (he touches his hip) and put it here (he touches his ankle) to fix it. And get a pin, just put it in and stitch it, then they wait till they heal it.’ He smiles and jokes about the forthcoming procedure: ‘Then I’ll get a wheelchair – be lazy all the time, I like that, better than crutches.’
Danny’s parents are less sanguine: they have just learned that another large tumour has to be removed from his left leg stump. They feel that they have little choice but to consent to a further amputation if that proves necessary during the additional surgery, which will be done at the same time as the limb lengthening. They have not told Danny that his entire leg may have to be amputated. He knows about the new tumour, and has said ‘I don’t mind them taking the tumour, but I don’t want them taking any more of my leg away’. Danny’s father says, ‘You feel that everyone is doing what they believe to be in his best interest, but they are tending to work a little bit blind’.
ACTIVITY: Stop at this point in the story and complete your checklist in relation to the limb lengthening of Danny’s right fibula and possible left leg amputation. Has a meaningful consent been obtained? Has the child’s voice been heard? What about the parents’ position?
In the event it proved possible to save the remaining left leg, and the right leg grew well, although Danny suffered a great deal of pain from the limb lengthening procedure. Now the surgeons want to lengthen the small stump below Danny’s left knee. Danny’s stepmother explained to the boy that this will give greater leverage to the prosthesis, but Danny said adamantly, ‘I don’t want them doing that!’. He would not explain why; he looked tired and depressed now, with dark circles under his eyes and little of his former chirpy manner. The surgeon gave the family three months to think about it, though he hinted that ‘It would be interesting to see how the leg responds’. Danny’s stepmother was sceptical about the surgeon’s motive: ‘Is he really thinking about what’s for Danny’s benefit, or is he just curious?’ Danny’s father replied, ‘He genuinely felt that there was some advantage to Danny’. But Danny’s stepmother argued, ‘He’s going to senior school soon, he doesn’t want another six months in a wheelchair’.
In the end, the family refused consent for lengthening the left leg stump.

data.vignette: A 10-year-old boy with neurofibromatosis has had repeated orthopedic surgeries, including a below-knee amputation on the left and recent limb-lengthening on the right that caused prolonged severe pain and months of limited mobility. A new operation is offered to lengthen the short left stump to improve leverage for his prosthesis as he grows. It would require another course of external fixation, frequent adjustments, and a long period in a wheelchair, with uncertain emotional toll after his last experience. The boy says he wants no more procedures on the stump and becomes withdrawn when asked to explain. His father thinks the added length could help him walk more independently long-term, while his stepmother worries about another painful, isolating recovery as he starts a new school year. Hospital policy and state law support either proceeding with parental consent or deferring given his sustained objection. The surgeon needs a plan within the next few weeks to align with the growth window and scheduling.
data.choice_1: Schedule left stump-lengthening surgery with external fixation.
data.choice_2: Do not lengthen the stump and continue prosthetic fitting and rehabilitation.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften language that implies stump-lengthening is the medically superior path to independence. For example, change “to improve leverage for his prosthesis…help him walk more independently long-term” to “to potentially improve prosthetic leverage as he grows, though functional gains are variable and some children do well with optimized prosthetic fitting without further surgery.” Add a balancing sentence describing credible benefits/limitations of the non-operative path (e.g., advanced prosthetic options, intensive rehab, but possible ongoing gait inefficiency/fit challenges as he grows) so the ethical tension is not decided by presumed clinical superiority.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so one is not framed as obviously more humane. Currently Choice 1 is described with vivid prior ‘prolonged severe pain,’ ‘isolating recovery,’ and ‘uncertain emotional toll,’ while the benefit is only speculative (‘could help him walk more independently’), making Choice 2 look clearly preferable. To restore equipoise: (1) Clarify that not lengthening has meaningful downsides (e.g., increasing difficulty maintaining a stable prosthetic fit as he grows, higher risk of falls/skin breakdown, likely need for major revision later when the growth window closes). (2) Add clinically plausible mitigations for surgical burden (e.g., multidisciplinary pain plan, child-life/psych support, option for inpatient rehab, clearer expected functional gain). (3) Make the boy’s objection more ethically complex rather than purely avoidance—e.g., he understands the tradeoff but prioritizes starting school/peer integration now, or he is ambivalent and requests more time—so proceeding is not automatically ‘overriding a traumatized child.’ (4) Remove or neutralize evaluative wording like ‘prolonged severe pain’ unless you add parallel burdens to Choice 2, such as persistent functional limits and ongoing rehab challenges.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce value-laden or emotionally weighted wording that implicitly discourages surgery. For example, change “prolonged severe pain” to “significant postoperative pain,” “painful, isolating recovery” to “prolonged recovery with limited mobility,” and “uncertain emotional toll” to “psychosocial impact is difficult to predict.” Describe the child’s response more neutrally (e.g., “declines and is reluctant to discuss further” instead of “becomes withdrawn”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten sentences so each adds decision-relevant clinical/ethical context. Consider removing or condensing repetition about prior surgeries and recovery (e.g., merge into one sentence summarizing prior postoperative course), and clarify the indication in one line (functional prosthetic leverage/fit as child grows).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Keep both choices as parallel, similarly scoped action statements without extra plan elements. Revise Choice 2 to match Choice 1’s specificity (procedure vs deferral) and avoid bundling multiple interventions. Example: “Defer stump-lengthening surgery at this time.” If you need rehab/prosthetics included, shorten Choice 1 similarly (e.g., “Proceed with left stump-lengthening using external fixation.” / “Defer left stump-lengthening; continue current prosthetic management.”).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry that makes deferring feel safer/easier. Currently Choice 1 is framed with vivid harms (prolonged severe pain, isolating recovery) while Choice 2 is framed as a neutral default. Add meaningful moral/functional costs to Choice 2 (e.g., higher likelihood of progressive gait inefficiency, skin breakdown, repeated prosthetic refits, decreased future independence, possible need for more invasive surgery later, psychosocial impact of dependence) without using numbers. Also add non-trivial potential benefits and safeguards to Choice 1 (e.g., improved long-term socket fit and energy expenditure, multidisciplinary pain plan, child-life/psychology support, option to stop adjustments) so it’s not ‘pain now vs comfort now’. Rephrase loaded language: change 'prolonged severe pain' to 'significant pain despite multimodal management' and 'painful, isolating recovery' to 'prolonged, restrictive recovery with risk of distress.' Ensure both sides have ethically costly tradeoffs: proceeding risks harming trust/psychological well-being; deferring risks limiting function and creating future regret/avoidable disability.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because several realistic middle options exist: (1) defer decision for a defined period while addressing the boy’s concerns with child psychology/ethics consult, (2) schedule but with an explicit assent-building process and a stop-point if distress escalates, (3) trial of optimized prosthetic/rehab with reassessment before growth window closes, (4) shorter/alternative surgical approach or timing (e.g., postpone until after school transition). To force a true binary, explicitly rule out these hybrids: state that (a) the growth window and OR access mean it is now-or-not-for-years, (b) no less burdensome procedure is clinically appropriate, (c) delaying a few months would negate the expected benefit, and (d) the family cannot commit to a conditional plan because of travel/insurance/scheduling constraints. Alternatively, redefine the choices to make them mutually exclusive and time-bound: 'Proceed with surgery this month' vs 'Formally decline surgery for the foreseeable future (at least until adolescence)'.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, 'Hospital policy and state law support either proceeding with parental consent or deferring given his sustained objection' is vague and risks implying a clear legal/professional standard that resolves the case. Clarify the gray zone: specify that the patient lacks legal decisional authority but his dissent is ethically weighty; policies require an assent process and ethics review when a mature minor persistently objects to non-emergent surgery, yet they do not mandate honoring the objection. Add why standard NF/orthopedic guidance doesn’t settle it (e.g., evidence for functional benefit exists but varies by anatomy and tolerance; no consensus threshold for proceeding without assent in elective limb reconstruction). Remove or rephrase definitive-sounding language: replace with 'Policy permits either path after documented assent efforts and ethics consultation; no policy mandates one.'

data.vignette: A 10-year-old boy with neurofibromatosis had a left below-knee amputation and recently underwent right-sided limb-lengthening with significant postoperative pain despite multimodal management and months of restricted mobility. His orthopedic surgeon offers elective surgery to lengthen the short left residual limb using an external fixator. The goal is to potentially improve prosthetic leverage and socket fit as he grows, though functional gains are variable and some children do well with optimized prosthetics alone. Surgery would require weeks to months of frame adjustments, frequent visits, and another prolonged period of limited weight-bearing, with uncertain psychosocial impact. The team can offer a structured pain plan, child-life support, and inpatient rehabilitation. The boy declines, saying he wants to start a new school year without “another frame,” and he is reluctant to discuss further. His father wants to pursue any option that might reduce future dependence, while his stepmother worries about worsening distress and loss of trust. Hospital policy permits either approach after documented assent efforts and an ethics consult. Because of his current growth stage and OR access, delaying a few months would negate the expected benefit and there is no less burdensome procedure.
data.choice_1: Proceed with left stump-lengthening using external fixation.
data.choice_2: Defer stump-lengthening and continue prosthetic management without further surgery.

choice_2.choice: Defer stump-lengthening and continue prosthetic management without further surgery.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating that with prosthetic management alone he is already experiencing (or is very likely to experience) clinically significant problems—e.g., recurrent skin breakdown/poor socket fit, falls, or inability to ambulate safely—because the residual limb is too short, making lengthening the only realistic way to improve function.

Add a clause that OR time/external-fixator resources and rehab beds are scarce with a long waitlist, so doing this elective lengthening would displace other children with time-sensitive/medically necessary surgeries (or conversely, that it uses a dedicated elective pediatric ortho block that would otherwise go unused).

data.vignette: A 10-year-old boy with neurofibromatosis had a left below-knee amputation and recently underwent right-sided limb-lengthening with significant postoperative pain despite multimodal management and months of restricted mobility. He now has recurrent skin breakdown and unstable prosthetic fit on the left because the residual limb is very short, leading to falls and difficulty ambulating safely despite optimized prosthetics and repeated adjustments. His orthopedic surgeon offers elective surgery to lengthen the short left residual limb using an external fixator. The goal is to potentially improve prosthetic leverage and socket fit as he grows, though functional gains are variable and some children do well with optimized prosthetics alone. Surgery would require weeks to months of frame adjustments, frequent visits, and another prolonged period of limited weight-bearing, with uncertain psychosocial impact. The team can offer a structured pain plan, child-life support, and inpatient rehabilitation. The boy declines and is reluctant to discuss further. His father wants to pursue any option that might reduce future dependence, while his stepmother worries about worsening distress and loss of trust. OR time, external-fixator equipment, and pediatric rehab beds are scarce with a long waitlist, so scheduling this elective case would delay other children’s more time-sensitive orthopedic operations. Hospital policy permits either approach after documented assent efforts and an ethics consult. Because of his current growth stage and OR access, delaying a few months would negate the expected benefit and there is no less burdensome procedure.
